description: Used to transfer files across a network in active mode.
Used to establish a connection and send commands for file transfers.
Provides secure, encrypted remote access to the command-line interface of a host.
Provides unsecure, unencrypted remote access to the command-line interface of a host.
Used for unsecure message relay between Simple Mail Transfer Protocol servers.
Resolves friendly host names and fully qualified domain names to IP addresses.
Used by a server to provision IP address configurations and options to clients.
Used by a client to request a dynamic IP address configuration from a DHCP server.
Enables clients to request and receive unsecure web pages and resources.
An early mailbox access protocol used to retrieve email by downloading it to a local device.
Legacy Windows protocol used for name resolution over a local network.
Legacy Windows protocol used to establish sessions for services like file sharing.
A mailbox access protocol that supports permanent connections and managing mail on the server.
Used by management systems to query status information from network device agents.
Used by network device agents to report notable events or alerts to a management system.
Used to query and update a centralized X.500-based directory of network users and resources.
Uses TLS/SSL to provide secure, encrypted access to websites and web services.
Supports file and printer sharing on Windows networks, often called CIFS.
Modern secure port used by mail clients to submit messages for delivery using encryption.
Secure version of IMAP that uses TLS to encrypt mail retrieval and management.
Secure version of POP3 that uses TLS to encrypt the retrieval of email messages.
Microsoft protocol for secure remote graphical desktop connections.
